elements.title: game boards (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that scholars disagree on whether the earliest-known game boards (example pictured) date to the Neolithic or the Early Bronze Age?

elements.title: Aurora Rodrigues (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Estado Novo deprived Aurora Rodrigues of sleep for more than two weeks to induce hallucinations?

elements.title: Live into 85 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Hogmanay special Live into 85 was so shambolic it ended a 32-year tradition?

elements.title: Casey Washington (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Casey Washington made the game-winning score that ended a record nine-overtime college football game?

elements.title: giant panda (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the distinctive coloration of the giant panda appears to serve as camouflage in both winter and summer?

elements.title: Saparinah Sadli (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Saparinah Sadli defended one of her former students when Indonesia's State Intelligence Agency challenged her gendered exploration of the New Order regime?

elements.title: Alas! and Did My Saviour Bleed (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the 18th-century hymn "Alas! and Did My Saviour Bleed" has been criticised because its lyrics have singers call themselves a "worm"?

elements.title: Elizabeth Yeampierre (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Elizabeth Yeampierre has called Puerto Rico the "poster child for climate injustice" due to the devastation caused by Hurricane Maria?

elements.title: World's Museum (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Boston's World's Museum was a theatre, an aquarium, a menagerie, and a freak show?
